title: 108_s2568
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Benjamin Franklin Commemorative Coin Act". Benjamin Franklin made significant contributions to various fields, signed all of the nation's organizational documents, printed official currency for several colonies, proposed methods to fix exchange rates, designed the first American coin, and popularized the phrase "A Penny Saved is A Penny Earned." Benjamin Franklin popularized the phrase "A Penny Saved is A Penny Earned" to represent American virtues of hard work and economical living. He played a major role in designing the Great Seal of the United States and other American symbols. Franklin's image appeared on circulating coin and paper currency before 1979, and his portrait was featured on the official United States half dollar from 1948-1963. His work "Way to Wealth" symbolizes America's commitment to free enterprise. The Franklin Institute Science Museum in Philadelphia showcases an interactive approach to science and technology. The Franklin Institute in Philadelphia is dedicated to Benjamin Franklin and houses the first steam printing machine for coinage used by the United States Mint. It was named the Official National Monument to Franklin in 1976 and collaborated with other institutions in 2000 to commemorate the 300th anniversary of Franklin's birth in 2006. Congress passed the Benjamin Franklin Tercentenary Commission Act in 2002. The Tercentenary Commission Act (Public Law 107-202) established a panel of distinguished Americans to recommend Tercentenary programs, with the Franklin Institute as its administrative secretariat. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $1 silver coins with younger and older Franklin images on the obverse, each weighing 26.73 grams, having a diameter of 1.500 inches, and containing 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender. The coins minted under this Act, containing 90% silver and 10% copper, will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. Congress recommends striking the coins at the United States Mint in Philadelphia. The design of coins minted under this Act will be specified. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall be emblematic of Benjamin Franklin's life and legacy, featuring images of him as a young man and an older man, reflecting his roles as a patriot and statesman. The reverse of the coins minted under this Act will bear an image related to Benjamin Franklin's role in developing early coins and currency. Each coin will have a value designation, the year "2006" inscribed, and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities starting January 1, 2006, with sales possible before that date. Minting authority will cease after December 31, 2006.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

Coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at face value plus the cost of designing and issuing them. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. Coins can be sold individually or as sets. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES.

Sales of coins minted under this Act require a $10 surcharge per coin. The surcharges collected by the Secretary will be promptly paid to the Franklin Institute for the Benjamin Franklin Tercentenary celebration. The Institute will be audited as per the requirements of the United States Code.
